entry.title: Using Joule‚Äôs Async Feature to Communicate with a Custom BTP App
entry.content:
Today, we are going to use Joule‚Äôs asynchronous (async) feature to establish communication between Joule and a custom BTP app.
Joule has a limitation when handling responses that take longer than 45 seconds, so we need to enable the async feature to properly support long-running responses.

Step 1: Understand the Requirements

Before starting, please review the help documentation:
Asynchronous API Requests

The prerequisites are critical:

To enable asynchronous API requests:
‚Ä¢ IAS-enabled subaccount
    o The BTP subaccount must be integrated with SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS)
‚Ä¢ For callback support your backend has to:
    o Perform the actual asynchronous task.
    o Send a callback to Joule once complete.
‚Ä¢ A trust configuration must be set up between the backend system and Joule:
    o This requires implementation efforts on Joule integration configuration
    o To trigger this, create an AIPS requirement on the Joule component in Jira

If your account is not IAS-enabled yet, check this guide:
SCI Developer Guide ‚Äì Intro

If you are trying to enable the async feature of Joule on a SAP LoB product, you need to create an AIPS Jira ticket.

Step 2: App2App with IAS

To enable the async feature with IAS, we use the App2App approach.
If you are interested, learn the concepts of Inbound and Outbound App2App for SAP DAS:

Inbound

Outbound

Once familiar, you can start setting up trust between Joule and IAS by following:
IAS App2App Dev Setup

Our scenario is slightly simpler than the reference document.

In the documentation, the flow is: 

 Joule <-> devflow_proxy_app <-> downstream app (SAP Build Workzone)

Our goal is:

 Joule <-> custom app

This means we do not need a proxy layer in the IAS console.
We can directly link Joule's Cloud Identity Service to the custom app's Cloud Identity Service.
In my case, my custom app's CIS is named as "giaIas".

Step 3: Configure the Destination for Joule

Now, create a Destination at the subaccount level for Joule to consume.
Because we do not have a middle layer for redirecting, we do not need below property in destination configuration:

 tokenService.body.resource=urn:sap:identity:application:provider:name:proxy-to-target

Use the following destination settings: 

Name=DestionationName 
Type=HTTP 
URL=<target-api-url> 
ProxyType=Internet 
Authentication=OAuth2JWTBearer 
clientId=<custom_app_cis-clientID> 
clientSecret=<custom_app_cis-clientSecret> 
tokenServiceURL=<ias-host>/oauth2/token 
x_user_token.jwks_uri=<ias-host>/oauth2/certs 
apptoapp=true 
tokenService.body.token_format=jwt 
tokenService.body.client_id=<custom_app-clientID>
tokenService.addClientCredentialsInBody=false 
tokenServiceURLType=Dedicated

With this configuration, the Outbound setup is complete.
Joule can now send requests to this destination and forward them to your target URL with a JWT token.
Important: Save this token in your custom app‚Äîyou will need it again for the Inbound flow.

In your custom app, validate the token‚Äôs key ID and signature before continuing with your business logic.

Step 4: Inbound Direction (Callback to Joule)

Follow the setup instructions in the help documentation for Joule function part:
Asynchronous API Requests

To call Joule‚Äôs callback API from the custom app, you need to perform token exchange with IAS.

Before that, let's verify the Joule callback URL:

  1. Go to your BTP subaccount.

  2. Click Go to Application for Joule.

A browser window will open with ‚ÄúThe service is up and running‚Äù.Use the displayed base URL and append: 

 /api/joule/v1/callback

Example Joule callback API: 

 https://joulefunctions-xxxxx.<region>.sapdas.cloud.sap/api/joule/v1/callback

 

Step 5: Token Exchange

Before calling the Joule callback API, perform a token exchange using this form data with your IAS token endpoint:

form_data = { 
'grant_type': 'urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:jwt-bearer', 
'client_id': IAS_CLIENT_ID, 
'client_secret': IAS_CLIENT_SECRET, 
'assertion': <token>, 
'resource': 'urn:sap:identity:application:provider:name:proxy-to-joule' 
}

The <token> here is the token passed along with the outbound request mentioned earlier.

 

Step 6: Final Callback and Deplooyment

After exchanging the token, call the Joule callback API with the new token.
Joule will handle the rest of the flow and display the message you defined in your Joule function.

When deploying your custom app to BTP, make sure it is bound to the CIS service you created.
Your manifest.yml should look like this:

applications:
  - name: <name>
    path: .
    memory: 256M
    instances: 1
    buildpacks:
      - python_buildpack
    services:
      - giaIas
    env:
      FLASK_RUN_PORT: 8080

This ensures the app can properly communicate with IAS through the bound CIS instance.

At this point, this completes the setup of Joule‚Äôs asynchronous communication with a custom BTP application via App2App scenario.

It‚Äôs been an exciting journey to get this communication working through the App2App setup. I learned a lot of concepts along the way and am happy to share these findings with the community. If you notice anything inaccurate or have any questions, please don‚Äôt hesitate to leave a comment and I‚Äôd be glad to clarify or discuss further.

entry.title: Re: Regarding the update of business roles
entry.content:
Hello @naoakisaruyama 

Following the recent upgrade, some of your copied business roles no longer align with their corresponding SAP templates. Below is the recommended plan to bring them back in line safely

Use Manage Business Role Changes After Upgrade only when a single change affects one role; otherwise, modify in Maintain Business Role by comparing with the template and applying only necessary updates. SAP Help Portal-Best Practices for Managing Business Role Changes After an Upgrade

Monitor for deprecated catalogues and necessary successors or dependencies; replace them accordingly, then retest app launch and restrictions. SAP Help Portal-Business Catalogues-Identity and Access Management

Re-evaluate restrictions after adoption Write/Read/Value Help.  SAP Learning: Maintaining Business Role Restrictions

Transport updated roles from Q to P via Export/Import Software Collection to maintain system consistency. SAP Help Portal-Identity and Access Management-How to Import and Export Business Roles

Let me know if it works

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Tax Compliance Tool
entry.content:
Hello Harish

Thank you for your question.

SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) is designed to manage key VAT compliance processes. It covers activities such as extracting transactional data, preparing VAT returns, enabling electronic submissions, and providing workflow approvals with full audit trails. The compliance calendar also helps keep track of important deadlines, and workflow notifications can be set up through DRC or integrated SAP workflow tools.

However, it‚Äôs important to note that VAT payment execution itself is not handled directly within DRC. Payment tracking usually requires support from SAP‚Äôs financial modules. The ‚ÄòRun Statutory Reports‚Äô FIORI app mainly focuses on statutory report generation and submission, so it does not address the entire VAT lifecycle.

In summary, DRC offers strong end-to-end VAT reporting, submission, and workflow features, while VAT payment tracking is typically managed through financial system integration.

Best regards,

John

entry.title: Re: How to rewrite this ABAP SQL join via the CDS associations and SQL Path Expression?
entry.content:
Hi @Sandra_Rossi , 

You can rewrite the SQL Queries as CDS views like this , 

I have directly converted the SQL query to CDS : 

1. 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'I_billing_doc_to_cost_center'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZI_billing_doc_to_cost_center
  as select from I_PrelimBillingDocumentItem as PBDI
    inner join   I_SalesDocument             as SD  on SD.SalesDocument = PBDI.SalesDocument
    inner join   I_PurchaseOrderItem         as POI on POI.PurchaseOrder = SD.PurchaseOrderByCustomer
{
  PBDI.PrelimBillingDocument,
  PBDI.PrelimBillingDocumentItem,
  PBDI.SalesDocument,
  SD.PurchaseOrderByCustomer,
  POI.CostCenter
}
where
      PBDI.PrelimBillingDocument =  'PBD0000061'
  and POI.CostCenter             <> ' '

IF you want to keep the PrelimBillingDocument as a parameter , you can also do the same like :

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'I_billing_doc_to_cost_center'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZI_billing_doc_to_cost_center
  with parameters
    p_PrelimBillingDocument : prelim_billing_document
  as select from I_PrelimBillingDocumentItem as PBDI
    inner join   I_SalesDocument             as SD  on SD.SalesDocument = PBDI.SalesDocument
    inner join   I_PurchaseOrderItem         as POI on POI.PurchaseOrder = SD.PurchaseOrderByCustomer
{
  PBDI.PrelimBillingDocument,
  PBDI.PrelimBillingDocumentItem,
  PBDI.SalesDocument,
  SD.PurchaseOrderByCustomer,
  POI.CostCenter
}
where
      PBDI.PrelimBillingDocument = $parameters.p_PrelimBillingDocument
  and POI.CostCenter             <> ' '

2. First create a view like : 

 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'I_billing_doc_to_cost_center'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZI_billing_doc_to_cost_center

  as select from I_PrelimBillingDocumentItem as PBDI
  association to I_SalesDocument     as _salesdocument        on _salesdocument.SalesDocument = PBDI.SalesDocument
  association to I_PurchaseOrderItem as __zzpurchaseorderitem on __zzpurchaseorderitem.PurchaseOrder = $projection.PurchaseOrderByCustomer

{

  PBDI.CostCenter,
  PBDI.SalesDocument,
  _salesdocument.PurchaseOrderByCustomer as PurchaseOrderByCustomer,
  _salesdocument,
  __zzpurchaseorderitem
}
where
  PBDI.CostCenter <> ' '

and on top of this create another view like : 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'I_billing_doc_to_cost_center2'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZI_billing_doc_to_cost_center2

  as select from ZI_billing_doc_to_cost_center as BDCC


{

  PBDI.CostCenter,


  _salesdocument,
  __zzpurchaseorderitem
}

Hope it Helps üôÇ

entry.title: Planned vs Unplanned Depreciation Behavior after Post-Capitalization
entry.content:
Description:

Client Requirement (with example):

  • Asset capitalization: 100,000
  • Useful life: 10 years ‚Üí planned depreciation = 10,000/year
  • After 2 years, 20,000 depreciation should already be recognized.
  • Remaining depreciation = 80,000, to be spread across 8 years ‚Üí 10,000/year.
  • Expected: System should spread depreciation based on remaining NBV (80,000) and remaining useful life (8 years)

Testing Performed:

  1. Created an asset with acquisition value 100,000, UY = 10.
  2. Posted Unplanned Depreciation = 20,000.
  3. Changed useful life to 8 years.

Problem Observed:

  • With Planned Depreciation Key ‚Üí system distributes planned depreciation automatically, but does not allow unplanned depreciation postings.
  • With Manual Depreciation Key ‚Üí unplanned depreciation can be posted, but planned depreciation is no longer distributed.
  • This means the system is not handling both requirements together (automatic periodic depreciation + extraordinary depreciation).

We have tested the following scenario to meet the client‚Äôs requirement:

  1. Posted an acquisition with 10-year useful life and depreciation key LINS (which distributes depreciation automatically).
  2. Posted Unplanned Depreciation = 20,000. For this, we had to temporarily change the depreciation key to manual, since LINS did not allow the posting.
  3. This enabled unplanned depreciation, but removed the distribution of planned depreciation.
  4. After posting unplanned depreciation, we attempted to reduce the useful life to 8 years and switch the depreciation key back to LINS.At this stage, the system throws an error, as unplanned depreciation has already been posted.

We understand this may be standard system behavior and would appreciate it if you could confirm this. Additionally, if possible, please suggest an approach to achieve the client‚Äôs requirement in S/4HANA
